Fig. 1 Acetone conversion as a function of reaction temperature over x wt% Pt/TiO2 (x = 0–4.14) under the reaction conditions of acetone concentration = 1000 ppm, acetone/O2 molar ratio = 1/400, and SV = 40,000 mL/(g h). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of (a) TiO2, (b) 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, (c) 0.11 wt% Pt/TiO2, (d) 0.17 wt% Pt/TiO2, (e) 0.46 wt% Pt/TiO2, (f) 0.68 wt% Pt/TiO2, (g) 1.40 wt% Pt/TiO2, (h) 3.07 wt% Pt/TiO2, and (i) 4.14 wt% Pt/TiO2. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) SEM, (b) TEM and (c) aberration-corrected STEM images, as well as (d–f) EDX elemental mapping of the 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalyst. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 H2-TPR profiles of (a) TiO2, (b) 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, (c) 0.17 wt% Pt/TiO2, (d) 0.46 wt% Pt/TiO2, and (e) 0.68 wt% Pt/TiO2. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) Acetone conversion as a function of on-stream reaction time, and effect of (b, c) water vapor, (d) CO2, and (e) SO2 on acetone conversion over 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 at 270 °C. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Acetone conversion as a function of reaction temperature over the Ce, V, and W-doped 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts under the reaction conditions of acetone concentration = 1000 ppm, acetone/O2 molar ratio = 1/400, and SV = 40,000 mL/(g h). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (A) Ti 2p, (B) O 1 s, (C) Pt 4f, (D) Ce 3d, (E) V 2p, and (F) W 4f XPS spectra of (a) 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, (b) 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, (c) 0.54 wt% V2O5-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, and (d) 0.55 wt% WO3-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Effect of SO2 on acetone conversion over (a) 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 at 250 °C, (b) 0.54 wt% V2O5-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 at 270 °C, and (c) 0.55 wt% WO3-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 at 270 °C. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 NH3-TPD profiles of (a) 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, (b) 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, (c) 0.54 wt% V2O5-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, and (d) 0.55 wt% WO3-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 in situ DRIFTS spectra of acetone adsorption on 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalyst at 40 °C. Graphical abstract Supported 0.05 wt% Pt catalysts, prepared via an in situ molten salt method, show high catalytic activity for acetone removal. Ce-, V-, or W-doping increases the amount of surface acid sites, and then enhances H2O-, CO2-, and SO2-tolerance of 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2. The present Pt catalysts might be suitable for oxygenated VOCs removal. Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) cause damage to atmospheric environment and human health. Supported noble metal catalysts are widely used to control VOCs emissions. The high cost, and low H2O-, CO2-, and SO2-resistance of such catalysts are worthy to be improved. Herein we fabricated Ce-, V-, or W-doped TiO2 supported ultralow loading Pt catalysts via the in-situ molten salt method, and evaluated their catalytic performance for acetone (major pollutants in pharmaceutical industry) removal. Under the present reaction conditions, all the catalysts exhibited high catalytic activity and stability for acetone oxidation, with the temperature required 90% acetone conversion being of 245 °C over 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2. The doping of Ce, V, or W enhanced the H2O-, CO2-, and SO2-tolerance ability of 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2. More than 85 %85%, 70%, or 60% of acetone could be removed even in the presence of 20 vol% water vapor, 10 vol% CO2, or 100 ppm SO2, respectively. The improvement in SO2-tolerance ability was due to the inhibition of SO2 adsorption and oxidation activity as well as Ti(SO4)2 or TiOSO4 formation. Acetone complete oxidation over 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 would follow the pathway: adsorbed acetone molecules → acetic acid and formic acid → carbonate species → CO2 and H2O. The present supported Pt catalysts might be suitable for oxygenated VOCs removal. Keywords Volatile organic compounds Catalytic oxidation Supported Pt catalyst Molten-Salt method H2O CO2 SO2-resistance 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emitted from various indoor environments, transportation activities and industrial processes, are harmful to the atmospheric environment and human health [1–3]. As one of the representative VOCs, acetone is a common solvent, and extensively used in plastic, rubber, fiber, drug, and pharmaceutical industry [4]. It has anesthetic effects on the central nervous system, and causes damage to our kidney and pancreas. Hence control the emission of acetone is rather in need [5,6]. Several technologies, such as adsorption, biodegradation, photocatalysis, and catalytic oxidation, have been successfully adopted for VOCs abatement [7–11]. Among them, catalytic combustion seems to be one of the most promising methods, owing to its high efficiency and low operation temperature. However, the key issue is the availability of high-efficiency catalysts. Due to their high catalytic performance (e.g. activity and stability), supported noble metal catalysts have received great attention for the oxidation of VOCs [12, 19]. For example, Zhang et al. [13] reported that TiO2 supported 1 wt% Pt, Rh, Pd, or Au catalysts showed high activity for HCHO oxidation, HCHO could be completely oxidized into CO2 and H2O at room temperature and space velocity = 50,000 h―1 over 1 wt% Pt/TiO2. Jia and co-workers [14] found that 0.82 wt% Pt-loaded mesoporous Cr2O3 catalyst exhibited good catalytic activity for toluene combustion, with T 50% and T 90% (the temperature required 50% and 90% conversion of toluene) being of 140 and 144 °C at space velocity = 20,000 mL/(g h), respectively. Zhang et al. [15] reported that hierarchical porous mordenite supported 0.78 wt% Pt catalyst was highly active for toluene oxidation, with T 50% and T 90% being of 175 and 190 °C at space velocity = 60,000 mL/(g h), respectively. Peng et al. [16] found that toluene conversion did not decrease over the CeO2 supported Pt (particle size = 1.8 nm) nanocatalyst within 60 h on-stream reaction. In addition to supported noble metal catalysts, transition metal oxide catalysts are also widely used in VOCs oxidation reactions [17–22]. For example, Zhao et al. [20] found that the CoAlO catalyst obtained via the thermal decomposition method exhibited high catalytic activity for acetone oxidation, due to the abundant surface Co3+ and good low temperature reducibility. Although supported noble metal catalysts were effective for the catalytic oxidation of VOCs, they were not catalytically durable in the presence of carbon dioxide-, water-, and sulfur dioxide [23–25]. Besides, the high loading of noble metals also limits their practical application. Hence, reducing the amount of noble metals of a catalyst and enhancing its catalytic activity and stability are always hot topics in practical application. Previously, we developed a novel strategy, the in-situ molten salt method, for the preparation of Mn2O3 supported Ag catalysts, and found that the obtained catalysts with 0.13 wt% Ag loadings were highly active for toluene oxidation. Unfortunately, these catalysts performed poor catalytic stability during the on-stream reaction [26]. Compared with Ag, Pt possessed stronger ability for the adsorption and activation of reactants. Besides, as a versatile support, TiO2 possess much better stability than Mn2O3 [27]. Herein, we report the fabrication of TiO2 supported 0.05 wt% Pt catalysts via the in-situ molten salt method, and their catalytic performance evaluation for the removal of acetone (major pollutants emitted from the pharmaceutical industry). To further improve their tolerance ability, particular of sulfur dioxide resistance, the effect of doping Ce, V, or W into TiO2 were carefully investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation NaNO3 (99.0%), NaF (99.0%), H2PtCl6.6H2O (Pt≥37.0%), Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (99.0%), and acetone (99.0%) were purchased from Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. H28N6O41W12 (99.5%) was purchased from Aladdin. TiO2 (99.0%) powder and NH4VO3 (99.0%) were purchased from Tianjin Fuchen Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All the chemicals were used without further purification. The x wt% Pt/TiO2 (x = 0–4.14) catalysts were synthesized by the in-situ molten salt strategy. In a typical preparation process, 0.5 mL of H2PtCl6 (0.01 mol/L) aqueous solution was added dropwise into the mixture of 29.4 g NaNO3, 0.6 g NaF, and 1.0 g TiO2 and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Then the mixture was well ground, and calcined in a muffle furnace from room temperature to 300 °C (heating rate = 1 °C/min) for 3 h. The as-obtained product was washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times to remove Na+, NO3 −, and F− ions, and then dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight. The results of inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopic (ICP-AES) investigations revealed that the real loading (x) of noble metals were 0.05, 0.11, 0.17, 0.46, 0.68, 1.40, 3.07, and 4.14 wt% in x wt% Pt/TiO2, respectively. The Ce-, V-, or W-doped 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts were fabricated via the same method, with the addition of precursor solution containing Ce, V, or W, respectively. The cerium precursor solution (0.1 mol/L) was aqueous solution of cerium nitrate. The vanadium (0.04 mol/L) and tungsten (0.08 mol/L) precursor solution were obtained by dissolving ammonium metavanadate and ammonium metatungstate with 0.5 mol/L oxalic acid solution, respectively. 2.2 Cayalyst characterization and catalytic performance evaluation The physicochemical properties of the x wt% Pt/TiO2 (x = 0–4.14) and Ce-, V-, or W-doped 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts were characterized via inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopic (ICP-AES), X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-angle annular dark field (HAADF) and element mapping, hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), nitrogen adsorption-desorption, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and NH3 temperature programmed-desorption (NH3-TPD) techniques. Furthermore, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFT) was carried out to propose the possible reaction mechanism. Catalytic performance of the present catalysts was evaluated in a continuous flow fixed-bed quartz tubular microreactor. The typical reaction conditions were: acetone concentration = 1000 ppm, acetone/O2 molar ratio = 1/400, and space velocity = 40,000 mL/(g h). The outlet gases were on-line analyzed using the gas chromatography (GC). The intermediate products were identified using an Agilent GC 7890B coupled with an Agilent 5977 A MS detector (Agilent, Santa Clara, CA, USA). The outlet by-products were first collected by Tenax-TA tube, and then the trapped gases were released to a thermal desorption instrument which was connected with the GC/MS analyzer. In addition, we also investigated the catalytic performance in the presence of 2.5, 5.0, 10.0, or 20.0 vol% H2O, 5.0 or 10.0 vol% CO2, and 100-ppm SO2. The detailed characterization and evaluation procedures were described in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activities and characterizations of the x wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts Shown in Fig. 1 and Table 1 are the catalytic activities of the x wt% Pt/TiO2 (x = 0–4.14) catalysts. Generally, acetone conversion increased with the rise in reaction temperature, and a small loading of Pt onto TiO2 greatly enhanced the catalytic activities for acetone oxidation. The temperature required 50% and 90% conversion of acetone (denoted as T 50% and T 90%) over TiO2 was 315 and 345 °C, while T 50% and T 90% over 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 obviously decreased to 236 and 274 °C, respectively. Besides, the catalytic activities of Pt/TiO2 were gradually improved with a further loading of Pt from 0.05 to 4.14 wt%. The 3.07 wt% Pt/TiO2 and 4.14 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts exhibited very similar catalytic activities, the later one performed the best, and its T 50% and T 90% for acetone oxidation were 172 and 195 °C, respectively. Indeed, calculating the turnover frequencies (TOFs) related to the amount of surface active sites (e.g. surface platinum atoms) is a good way to compare catalytic activities of the supported noble metal catalysts. However, it is hard to determine the accurate active sites. Hence, we herein used TOFM (TOFM = mC 0/n M) and specific reaction rates (specific reaction rates = mC 0/w M) to compare their catalytic activities, where m is the acetone conversion at a typical temperature (e.g., 140 °C), C 0 (mol/s) is the initial acetone concentration per second, n M (mol) is the molar amount of noble metal or oxide, and w is the weight of noble metal or oxide. As shown in Table 1, 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, 0.11 wt% Pt/TiO2, and 0.17 wt% Pt/TiO2 exhibited much higher TOFPt and specific reaction rates than that of 3.07 wt% Pt/TiO2 and 4.14 wt% Pt/TiO2. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the x wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts. One can easily found that the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 25.3°, 37.8°, 48.0°, 53.9°, 55.1°, 62.7°, 75.0°, and 76.0° could be well indexed according to the standard TiO2 sample (JCPDS PDF No. 21-1272). The loading of Pt did not change the crystal structure of TiO2. Besides, no obvious diffraction signals could be ascribable to the noble metal phase, due to the low loading and/or high dispersion of Pt on TiO2 surface. Fig. 3 gives the SEM, TEM and STEM as well as the EDX elemental mapping images of the 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalyst. One could find that the TiO2 support displayed an irregular morphology with particle size of 200 nm. Usually, it is very useful to adopt HAADF-STEM technique to characterize noble metal particles. In the present study, we focused on the supported 0.05 wt% Pt catalysts. Maybe the Pt loading was as low as 0.05 wt%, it was hard for us to find the Pt particles (or clusters). As shown in Fig. 3c‒f, the present Pt species were well dispersed on the surface of the TiO2 support. The interaction (Pt° + TiO2 → Ptδ + + TiO2‒ y ) between Pt and TiO2 could be verified by the H2-TPR experiments (Fig. 4 ). There were a small reduction peak in the range of 450–650 °C and a large reduction peak at 650 °C over TiO2, which corresponding to the reduction of surface and bulk lattice oxygen of TiO2 [28]. For x wt% Pt/TiO2, the weak reduction peak appeared at 90 °C was due to the reduction of Ptδ + to Pt°, and the other peaks could be ascribed to the reduction of lattice oxygen species of TiO2 [29]. With the loading of Pt, the peaks related to reduction of surface lattice oxygen species gradually shifted to lower temperatures. That is to say, the reactivity of surface lattice oxygen species was enhanced with the loading of Pt onto TiO2. As we know, various mechanisms, including the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism, the Eley-Riedeal (E–R) mechanism, and the Mars-van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism, had been proposed for VOCs complete oxidation [30–34]. Whatever the mechanism, the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules were very important. In the present catalytic system, acetone molecules were adsorbed on the main active sites of the Pt-TiO2 interface [12], and then reacted with the surface reactive lattice oxygen species to generate CO2 and H2O. Therefore, it is understandable that the present Pt/TiO2 catalyst with higher loading exhibited better catalytic activity for acetone oxidation. 3.2 Catalytic stabilities and H2O-, CO2-, and SO2-resistance of the 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalyst In addition to catalytic activity, catalytic stability and water-, carbon dioxide-, and sulfur dioxide-resistance were also rather critical for commercial catalysts [21,35,36]. Although 4.14 wt% Pt/TiO2 performed better than 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, the much higher loading of Pt limited its practical application. Hence, we investigated catalytic stability of the 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalyst. There was no significant drop of acetone conversion been observed within 40 h on-stream reaction at 270 °C over 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 (Fig. 5 a), indicating that 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 was stable under the present reaction condition. Furthermore, because the supported Pt catalysts were obtained after calcination at 300 °C, while under present reaction conditions, acetone could be completely oxidized below 300 °C (Fig. 1). Therefore, we believe that the existence of Pt agglomeration phenomena could be discarded. With the addition of 2.5 vol% water vapor into the reactant, 6% loss in acetone conversion was detected over 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, when 2.5 vol% water vapor was cut off, acetone conversion could restore to the original value (Fig. 5b), suggesting the inhibition by water vapor was reversible. Such a phenomenon could be due to the competitive adsorption between water vapor and acetone molecules [37]. Since the humidity in environment is much higher, we evaluated catalytic activity at higher concentration of water vapor over 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2. One can observe that acetone conversions decreased from 86 to 80, 77, 75, and 72%, when 2.5, 5.0, 10.0, and 20.0 vol% water vapor introduced into the reaction system (Fig. 5c), respectively. It should be noted that the deactivation by water vapor over 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 was revisable even at a high water vapor concentration of 20.0 vol%. In addition to H2O, CO2 is another product from the complete oxidation of acetone. Partial catalytic active sites of 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 might be covered by the adsorbed CO2 molecules and/or carbonates via the reaction between CO2 and surface hydroxyls [38,39], thus resulting in the decrease of catalytic activity. With the adding of 5.0 vol% and 10.0 vol% CO2 into the reaction system, acetone conversions at 270 °C decreased from 86% to 84 and 80% over 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 (Fig. 5d). The loss in the catalytic activity of 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 due to the presence of CO2 could not be recovered after the cutting off of CO2, while it could be made up after pretreatment in O2 at 300 °C for 1 h, because of the desorption of adsorbed CO2 molecules and/or carbonates from 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 [40,41]. In some cases, the emissions emitted from the pharmaceutical industry might include inorganic and organic sulfur species, which could be transferred into SO2 during the catalytic oxidation process. It was generally accept that SO2 would poison supported noble metal catalysts in oxidation reaction. So it is important to investigate the SO2 tolerance ability of a supported noble metal catalyst. In the present study, acetone conversion largely decreased from 86 to 46% within 15 h on-stream reaction at 270 °C after adding of 100 ppm SO2 over 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 (Fig. 5e). Different from the addition of water vapor and CO2, the deactivation of 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 by SO2 was irreversible, since acetone conversion could only be restored to 60% after activation in O2 at 300 °C for 1 h. In order to figure out the reason of deactivation, FT-IR spectra were collected over the fresh and deactivated 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts, and the bands appeared at 580, 612, 1637, and 3417 cm−1 (Fig. S1). The adsorption bands that at 3417 cm−1 could be assigned to stretching vibration of surface hydroxyl, that at 1637 cm−1 could be attributed to the presence of surface water molecules, and that in the range of 400–1000 cm−1 could be belonged to Ti-O bond vibration [42,43]. It was obvious that a new adsorption band at 1110 cm−1 due to the SO3 2‒ or SO4 2‒ species was detected over the deactivated 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalyst [44]. In other words, the irreversible deactivation by SO2 over 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 was related to the formation of sulfate. 3.3 Catalytic activities of the Ce, V, or W-doped 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts Obviously, 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 exhibited very good catalytic stability, and tolerance of water vapor and CO2 for acetone oxidation. However, its SO2-tolerance ability was still hard to meet the need in practical application. (Ce-doped) V2O5-WO3/TiO2, as a typical catalytic system, has been widely used for the catalytic removal of NO x , and exhibited relatively high resistance to SO2 poisoning [45]. Therefore, we carefully investigated the effect of doping Ce, V, or W into 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 on catalytic performance for acetone oxidation. As can be seen from Fig. 6 a, the doping of Ce could improve the catalytic activity of 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2. The catalytic activities of the Ce-doped 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts increased with the rise in CeO2 amount from 0 to 0.57 wt%, but then decreased with a further increase of CeO2 amount from 0.57 to 1.61 wt%. Among them, the 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalyst performed the best with the lowest T 90% of 245 °C (Table 2 ). That is to say, the optimal doping amount of CeO2 was 0.57 wt%. For comparison, the V- or W-doped 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts with similar loadings to Ce were also generated by the in-situ molten salt method. Analogously, 0.54 wt% V2O5-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 and 0.55 wt% WO3-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 performed better than 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 (Fig. 6b). As demonstrated in Table 2, TOFs and specific reaction rates for acetone oxidation at 140 °C of the samples were calculated. Obviously, for different doping species, the TOFPt decreased in the order of 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 (16.22 × 10−3 s−1)> 0.55 wt% WO3-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 (9.40 × 10−3 s−1)> 0.54 wt% V2O5-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 (7.87 × 10−3 s−1). The specific reaction rates followed the same sequence of TOFPt. From above, it was clear that the 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalyst exhibited the highest catalytic activity for acetone oxidation. For the supported noble metal catalysts, the noble metal dispersion is very important for the catalytic performance. We tried to calculate the Pt dispersion of the supported 0.05 wt% Pt catalysts via the static chemical absorption method using H2 as probe molecules. However, the data were very different, possible due to the low Pt loading and the hydrogen spillover. In the present study, because all of the catalysts were prepared via the same method, and the BET surface area of 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, 0.54 wt% V2O5-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, and 0.55 wt% WO3-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 was 14, 14, 11, and 11 m2/g, respectively, we thought there might be little difference in Pt dispersion with similar loadings. In order to further characterize the surface compositions of the supported 0.05 wt% Pt catalysts, we carried out the XPS experiments. Fig. 7 illustrates the Ti 2p, Ce 3d, V 2p, W 4f, O 1 s and Pt 4f XPS spectra of the Ce, V, or W-doped 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts. In the Ti 2p XPS spectra (Fig. 7A), two symmetry peaks at 458.4 and 464.1 eV were detected due to Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2, respectively. These peaks were characteristic signals of Ti4+ [46,47]. In the O 1 s XPS spectra (Fig. 7B), the asymmetrical O 1 s spectrum of each sample could be divided into three components: one at 529.6 eV was attributed to the surface lattice oxygen (Olatt) species, one at 531.3 eV was attributed to the surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads, O2 −, O2 2−, or O−) species, and the shoulder peak at 532.9 eV was attributed to the hydroxyl species [48–50]. In the Pt 4f XPS spectra (Fig. 7C), the asymmetrical Pt 4f7/2 and Pt 4f5/2 spectrum of each sample could be divided into two components at 70.4 and 71.4 eV, and 74.2 and 75.7 eV, respectively. The signals at 70.4 and 74.2 eV were due to Pt° species, while these at 71.4 and 75.7 eV were due to Pt2+ species [51–53]. In the Ce 3d XPS spectra (Fig. 7D), there were Ce 3d5/2 (denoted as v) and Ce 3d3/2 (denoted as u) peaks [54]. These peaks including v (881.7 eV), v” (888.0 eV), v”' (897.8 eV), u (900.5 eV), u” (906.3 eV), and u”' (916.0 eV) could be due to Ce4+ species, while that of v' (884.9 eV) and u' (903.2 eV) could be due to Ce3+ species [55–59]. The asymmetrical V 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 7E) could be divided into two peaks at 516.6 and 515.5 eV, indicating the presence of V5+ and V4+ species [60–62], respectively. In the W 4f XPS spectrum (Fig. 7F), there were W 4f5/2 and W 4f7/2 peaks at 37.4 and 35.6 eV, due to W6+ species [63,64]. Table 3 summarized the surface compositions of the Ce-, V-, and W-doped 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts. The surface Oads/Olatt and Pt2+/Pt molar ratios increased in the order of 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 <0.54 wt% V2O5-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 <0.55 wt% WO3-0.05% Pt/TiO2 <0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2. Because there was only Ti4+ on the TiO2 supports, a larger amount of surface Oads and Pt2+ species meant a higher concentration of oxygen vacancy, which was beneficial for the adsorption and activation of reactant molecular [65,66]. Therefore, it was understandable that 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 exhibited better catalytic activity than 0.55 wt% WO3-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 and 0.54 wt% V2O5-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2. 3.4 Catalytic stabilities and H2O-, CO2-, and SO2-resistance of the Ce, V, or W-doped 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts Within 50 h on-stream acetone oxidation at 250, 270, and 270 °C, no apparent loss of activity were detected over 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 (Fig. S2a), 0.54 wt% V2O5-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 (Fig. S3a), and 0.55 wt% WO3-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 (Fig. S4a), implying that our catalytic system was catalytic stable under the adopted conditions. The addition of 2.5, 5.0, 10.0, and 20.0 vol% water vapor into the reactant, made that acetone conversion at 250 °C decreased from 94 to 91, 89, 88, and 86% over 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 (Fig. S2b and c), that at 270 °C decreased from 93 to 87, 86, 85, and 84% over 0.54 wt% V2O5-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 (Fig. S3b and c), and that at 270 °C decreased from 93 to 89, 89, 88, and 87% over 0.55 wt% WO3-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 (Fig. S4b and c), respectively. Compared with 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, the descent degree of acetone conversion over the Ce-, V-, or W-doped catalysts obviously slowed down with the rise in water vapor concentration, and that more than 85% acetone could be removed even in the presence of 20.0 vol% water vapor. After cutting off water vapor, acetone conversion over the Ce-, V-, or W-doped 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts could be restored to the original value. Clearly, the doping of Ce, V, or W enhanced the water vapor tolerance ability of 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2. Similar to 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, a negative influence on acetone conversion due to the introduction of CO2 was observed over the Ce-, V-, or W-doped 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts (Figs. S2d, S3d, and S4d), and such an inhibition effect also could be restored after pretreatment in O2 at 300 °C for 1 h. It was generally accepted that the negative effect by CO2 was ascribed to the decrease in surface active sites, which were blocked by the carbonate species accumulation during the reaction [67,68]. Fig. 8 shows the influence on acetone conversion in the presence of 100 ppm SO2 over the Ce-, V-, or W-doped 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalysts. Within 15 h on-stream reaction, acetone conversion decreased by 25%, 30%, and 25% over 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 at 250 °C, 0.54 wt% V2O5-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 at 270 °C, and 0.55 wt% WO3-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 at 270 °C, respectively. After activation in O2 flow (20 mL/min) at 300 °C for 1 h, acetone conversion could be accordingly recovered to 80%, 75%, and 85% within 5 h on-stream reaction. As mentioned above, acetone conversion decreased by 40%, and it could be only restored to 60% over 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 under similar reaction conditions (Fig. 5e). It was apparent that the doping of Ce, V, or W largely enhanced the SO2 tolerance ability of 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2. It is well known that the deactivation in the presence of SO2 was primarily caused by the formation of sulfate and/or sulfite on the surface of a catalyst. The generation of sulfate and/or sulfite species over the Pt/TiO2-based catalysts might include adsorption of acidic SO2, oxidation of SO2 to SO3, and SO3 induced the formation of sulfate and/or sulfite species. Due to its excellent oxygen vacancy content and release capacity, ceria could provide some of the weak Lewis acid sites, on which bond with gaseous SO2 to form Ce(SO4)2 [69]. As reported in the literature [70,71], the formation of VOSO4 was the main reason for leading the decrease in the catalytic performance. Hence, the surface acidity of the present catalysts could give great effect on their SO2 tolerance ability. NH3 is believed to be one of suitable probe molecules for investigating the acidic property of a solid catalyst. The position and area of the NH3 desorption peak indicated the strength and amount of surface acid sites on the catalysts [72–74]. Fig. 9 gives the NH3-TPD profiles of the Pt/TiO2-based catalysts. It could be found that 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 showed a weak desorption peak in the range of 50–150 °C; 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 showed a strong desorption peak in the range of 50–150 °C, and a broad desorption peak in the range of 150–450 °C; both 0.54 wt% V2O5-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 and 0.55 wt% WO3-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 showed a tailing desorption peak in the range of 50–300 °C. Generally, most of the desorption peaks over the present catalysts could be due to NH3 molecules absorbed on the weak acid sites [75,76]. It was reported that the NH3 desorption peaks at lower temperature could be attributed to NH3 desorption from the weak Brønsted acidic sites [76,77], which were regarded as important active species at low temperature. In present study, the doping of Ce, V, or W increased the amount of surface acid sites, thus inhibiting the adsorption of acidic SO2. In addition, SO2 could be oxidized to form Ce2(SO4)3 over 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 due to the unique oxygen storage/release property of CeO2 [78,79], and to form VOSO4 over 0.54 wt% V2O5-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 thanks to basicity of the bridging V-O-Ti oxygen [80,81]. The consumption of SO2 in the generation of Ce2(SO4)3 or VOSO4 could effectively depress the formation of Ti(SO4)2 or TiOSO4. Wachs and co-workers [82,83] previously found that turnover frequency for SO2 oxidation over WO3/TiO2 was much lower than that over V2O5/TiO2, and suggested that WO3 modification was efficient to inhibit the oxidation of SO2. Hence, it was understandable that the doping of Ce, V, or W could enhance the SO2 tolerance ability of 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 (Fig. S5). 3.5 Possible mechanism of acetone oxidation over the Ce-doped 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalyst In order to investigate the possible reaction mechanism of acetone complete oxidation, in situ FTIR experiments on acetone adsorption at 40 °C, and in situ FTIR experiments on acetone oxidation at 100–300 °C over the best-performed 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalyst were carried out. Fig. 10 shows the in situ DRIFT spectra of 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 after exposure to acetone. The peaks that at 2973 and 2931 cm−1 were attributed to the stretching vibration of CH bond [84], that at 1702 cm−1 could be attributed to the stretching vibration of CO, and that at 1366 cm−1 could be attributed to the stretching vibration of CH3 on acetone [84,85]. Besides, the presence of two sharp bands at 3719 and 3670 cm−1 revealed the generation of OH groups with the adsorption of acetone [84]. The intensity of the peaks gradually increased with exposure time, indicating that the amount of acetone adsorbed on the catalyst continuously increased. In addition, the stretching vibration attributed to the carboxylate appeared at 1590 cm−1 [84], showing that a small amount of acetone might be oxidized to formic acid by the surface adsorbed oxygen species on catalyst. As shown in Fig. 11 , similar to above, these peaks at 3719, 3670, 2983, 2931, 1702, and 1366 cm−1 were related to the adsorption of acetone molecules. With the rise in temperature, some new signals could be observed. The band at 2100 cm−1 was due to the CO stretching modes [86]. The bands at 1350 and 1757 cm−1 were attributed to the symmetrical stretching vibration (νs) and asymmetrical stretching vibration (νas) of formate species (COO) [84], respectively. The band at 1444 cm−1 appeared above 150 °C, could be assigned to symmetrical stretching vibration of adsorbed acetate ions (νs(COO)) [84]. These results indicated that acetone was converted into acetic acid and formic acid. The band at 1223 cm−1 was ascribed to the ν(CO) modes in bidentate bridged carbonate, demonstrated the decomposed of acetic acid and formic acid. With the rise in temperature from 150 to 300 °C, the intensity of the peak (1702 cm‒1) due to the stretching vibration of CO of acetone gradually decreased, suggesting the reduction of acetone content. We also used GC–MS to detect the intermediate products of acetone oxidation over the 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalyst at T 10%, T 50%, and T 90%. As shown in Fig. 12 , there was acetic acid generation during the complete oxidation progress. On the basis of the in situ FTIR and GC–MS results, we tentatively proposed the mechanism of acetone oxidation over the Ce-doped 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 13 ). Acetone and oxygen molecules were first adsorbed on the catalyst surface. With an increase of reaction temperature, acetone was decomposed to acetic acid and formic acid, and then acetic acid and formic acid were converted to carbonate species. Finally, the carbonate species were completely decomposed to CO2 and H2O. 4 Conclusions In summary, Ce-, V-, or W-doped TiO2 supported ultralow loading Pt (0.05 wt%) catalysts were prepared via the in-situ molten salt method. The loading of Pt largely enhanced the catalytic activities of TiO2. All the catalysts exhibited good catalytic stability during the on-stream experiments for acetone oxidation under the adopted conditions. The doping of Ce, V, or W not only enhanced the catalytic activity of 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2, but also improved its H2O-, CO2-, and SO2-tolerance ability. Even after the addition of 20 vol% water vapor, 10 vol% CO2, or 100 ppm SO2 into the reactant, more than 85%, 70%, and 60% of acetone could be eliminated, respectively. The improvement in SO2-tolerance ability was due to (i) Ce, V, or W-doping increased the amount of surface acid sites, thus inhibiting the adsorption of acidic SO2; (ii) the generation of Ce2(SO4)3 or VOSO4 partially consumed SO2 molecules, then reduced the formation of Ti(SO4)2 or TiOSO4; and (iii) WO3 modification suppressed the oxidation of SO2. A plausible reaction mechanism for acetone oxidation over the Ce-doped 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 catalyst might follow the pathway: adsorbed acetone molecules → acetic acid and formic acid → carbonate species → CO2 and H2O. coredata.dc:description: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) cause damage to atmospheric environment and human health. Supported noble metal catalysts are widely used to control VOCs emissions. The high cost, and low H2O-, CO2-, and SO2-resistance of such catalysts are worthy to be improved. Herein we fabricated Ce-, V-, or W-doped TiO2 supported ultralow loading Pt catalysts via the in-situ molten salt method, and evaluated their catalytic performance for acetone (major pollutants in pharmaceutical industry) removal. Under the present reaction conditions, all the catalysts exhibited high catalytic activity and stability for acetone oxidation, with the temperature required 90% acetone conversion being of 245 °C over 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2. The doping of Ce, V, or W enhanced the H2O-, CO2-, and SO2-tolerance ability of 0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2. More than 85 %85%, 70%, or 60% of acetone could be removed even in the presence of 20 vol% water vapor, 10 vol% CO2, or 100 ppm SO2, respectively. The improvement in SO2-tolerance ability was due to the inhibition of SO2 adsorption and oxidation activity as well as Ti(SO4)2 or TiOSO4 formation. Acetone complete oxidation over 0.57 wt% CeO2-0.05 wt% Pt/TiO2 would follow the pathway: adsorbed acetone molecules → acetic acid and formic acid → carbonate species → CO2 and H2O. The present supported Pt catalysts might be suitable for oxygenated VOCs removal.
coredata.dc:title: Supported ultralow loading Pt catalysts with high H2O-, CO2-, and SO2-resistance for acetone removal
